subanswer.text:
Someone may argue against splitting costs equally because it doesn't take into account individual contributions or involvement prior to purchasing these items. Here are several reasons supporting various perspectives about equitable division versus negotiation/price adjustment strategies when dealing with shared expenses within families or groups:

**Equitable Cost Division Reasons Support (Equal Splitting)**:
1. **Fairness Perception**: Equal splits can seem fairer since everyone contributes financially regardless of their level of influence during buying decisions. This eliminates feelings of resentment among those who didn't participate actively but still bore part of the financial burden.
   
2. **Simplified Accountability Tracking**: With equal divisions, tracking which person owes whom becomes simpler; nobody arguing ownership complexities. It keeps things straightforward without delving deep into past interactions regarding specific transactions.  

3. **Encourages Responsibility & Consumption Control**: Knowing every member shares direct fiscal responsibilities encourages mindful consumption choices—people won't just buy stuff impulsively knowing all parties shoulder its cost! Reduces waste generation due to
